Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. Centered on Miyazawa’s own life, the film depicts his adolescence in the countryside, the ideals he intensively pursued before his unexpected death, the tremendous chaos and angst in the world after World War II, and the discord that continues to have a major impact on humankind even in today’s modern era.<|end_of_text|>

Okay. Here's the thing. I've read through the comments of other viewers --- some trashing the film and some saying it's the funniest, most enjoyable work of kubrick they've seen. This movie is good for some laughs and i think many of the critics are correct in saying kubrick offers traditional black comedy with an edge. However, I think the movie loses a dynamic tension it could have tapped into by not being as conventional as it actually is

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The teen, who secretly enjoys writing poetry and singing love songs, finds it very difficult to tell either his pals or anyone else that she and her boyfriend are not an item.
